bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 27, 1941

div1.p: Kean questions whether Ames' self-diagnosis of yellow fever was correct, because earlier he had claimed to be immune.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 27, 1941

opener.dateline:
Dec. 27
1941 2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.

div1.p:
This is a P. S. to my letter of
yesterday to answer your question about
the entry in the Lazear-Reed blank book
about the entry as to Dr Roger Post Ames
being sick in Hosp. Jan. 27 to Feb 1st
1901- General Ireland called me
on the phone some time ago and
asked me if a man could have
yellow fever and be well in 5 days
I said there were undoubtedly many
mild cases but I never knew of
one to get out as early as that and
asked what he had in mind. He
said that someone, I forget now who,
had been looking over the Sick & Wounded
Records in the Post Hospital and had
found this entry of Dr. R. P. Ames
and the diagnosis was yellow fever-
Ac
K
2.
I said that as Ames was a y. f. expert
he undoubtedly made his own diag-
nosis, but that he always claimed to
be an immune, and Reed selected
him on that account for duty at
Camp Lazear. Reed so states in his
description of Camp Lazear in the article
The Etiology of Yellow Fever, An Additional
Note Page 71 of Doc- 822- It happened
that I got my order on Jan 28 to go to
Washington for examination for promo-
tion and did not get back until
Feb. 20 so I never heard of this
until Ireland called me up a
year ago. I wonder if the record
shows that he had any albumen
There sometimes isnt any in the
very mild cases or any really diagnostic
symptom- Also second attacks are
a possibility as I heard Dr Finlay say
& as there are in small pox- It is a mystery.
With all blessings for you & Mrs Hench for the New Year
